title: Prunus nigra
text:
Prunus nigra, the Canada plum, Canadian plum, or black plum, is a species of "<a href="Prunus">Prunus</a>", native to eastern <a href="North%20America">North America</a> from <a href="Nova%20Scotia">Nova Scotia</a> west to <a href="Minnesota">Minnesota</a> and southeastern <a href="Manitoba">Manitoba</a>, and south as far as <a href="Connecticut">Connecticut</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, and <a href="Iowa">Iowa</a>. It formerly also grew in <a href="Ohio">Ohio</a> but is now thought to be extinct in that state. Isolated populations are present along streambanks in <a href="Saskatchewan">Saskatchewan</a> and <a href="Alberta">Alberta</a>, along <a href="Lake%20Timiskaming">Lake Timiskaming</a> in northern <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>, and along the <a href="Maine">Maine</a>-<a href="New%20Brunswick">New Brunswick</a> border, though this latter population is now severely threatened as the tree is a host for an <a href="aphid">aphid</a> that menaces the local <a href="potato">potato</a> crop and so many of the trees have been cut down.
Description.
"Prunus nigra" is a <a href="deciduous">deciduous</a> <a href="shrub">shrub</a> or small <a href="tree">tree</a> growing to tall with a trunk up to 25 cm diameter, with a low-branched, dense crown of stiff, rigid, branches. The <a href="Bark%20%28botany%29">bark</a> is gray-brown, older layers coming off in thick plates. The branchlets are bright green at first, later become dark brown tinged with red, and spiny. The winter buds are chestnut brown, long-pointed at the tip, up to long.
The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are <a href="Leaf%20shape">alternate, simple, and oblong-ovate or obovate</a>, long and broad, wedge-shaped, slightly heart-shaped, or rounded at base, doubly crenaulate-serrate, abruptly contracted to a narrow point at the apex, feather-veined, midrib conspicuous; they emerge from the bud convolute, downy, slightly tinged with red, are smooth, becoming bright green above and paler beneath when full grown. The leaf petioles are stout, bearing two large dark glands and early deciduous, lanceolate, and three to five-lobed stipules.
The <a href="flowers">flowers</a> are diameter, with five rounded petals, white fading to pale pink, with a more or less irregularly notched margin; they are slightly fragrant, borne in three to four-flowered umbels, with short, thick peduncles, and appear before the leaves in mid to late spring. The flower stalks are slender and dark red. The calyx is conic, dark red, five-lobed, the lobes acute, finally reflexed, glandular, smooth on the inner surface, imbricate in bud, ovate, with short claws, imbricate in bud. There are 15–20 stamens, inserted on the calyx tube; filaments thread-like; anthers purplish, introrse, two-celled; cells opening longitudinally; the pistil has a superior ovary in the bottom of calyx tube, one-celled, with two ovules.
The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is an oblong-oval <a href="drupe">drupe</a>, long with a tough, thick, orange red skin, free from bloom, yellow flesh adherent to the stone; the stone oval, compressed. It matures in late summer or early autumn. The <a href="cotyledon">cotyledon</a>s are thick and fleshy. The species grows best in alluvial soils.
It can easily be confused with the related "<a href="Prunus%20americana">Prunus americana</a>", differing most obviously in the leaf margins having blunt, gland-tipped teeth, rather than the sharp, glandless teeth of "P. americana" leaves.
A fungus in the genus "<a href="Taphrina">Taphrina</a>" often attacks the plums; the young ovaries swell, often much larger than full grown plums, become hollow and often persist on the tree in winter. Known as "plum pockets", they appear pale green, leathery to the touch, and hollow with the exception of a few fibrous bands. The disease reduces regeneration of the plums.
Uses.
The fruit is somewhat sour, clingstone, and very juicy. It can be eaten raw when fully ripe or cooked and made into pies <a href="Fruit%20preserves">preserve</a>s and jellies. Dried, these plums were a popular winter staple of indigenous peoples. French explorer <a href="Jacques%20Cartier">Jacques Cartier</a> remarked in his journal that he was presented with dried Canada plums by the <a href="St.%20Lawrence%20Iroquoians">St. Lawrence Iroquoians</a> in his first expedition to Canada. Early settlers in the western U.S. and Canada also made use of these wild plums for dried fruit, as popularized by the autobiographical novel "<a href="On%20the%20Banks%20of%20Plum%20Creek">On the Banks of Plum Creek</a>", the fourth book in <a href="Laura%20Ingalls%20Wilder">Laura Ingalls Wilder</a>'s "<a href="Little%20House%20on%20the%20Prairie">Little House on the Prairie</a>" series.
One of the few tree fruits indigenous to the <a href="upper%20Midwest">upper Midwest</a>, <a href="northern%20Ontario">northern Ontario</a> and the prairie provinces of Canada and capable of surviving the harsh winters there, efforts were made to breed improved cultivars of these plums in the 19th century. Notable varieties still grown today include "Assiniboine" and "Cheney". "Prunus nigra" has the same number of chromosomes as "<a href="Prunus%20salicina">Prunus salicina</a>", the cultivated Japanese plum, and so the two cross-pollinate readily. Breeding work in the 20th century resulted in improved "P. nigra x salicina" hybrid varieties that retain the high quality of Japanese plums and the hardiness of wild Canada plums, such as "Pembina", "Superior", and "Patterson Pride".
The <a href="wood">wood</a> is bright red brown; heavy, hard, strong, and close-grained, with a density of 0.6918. When wounded the wood turns an attractive red colour, and sawlogs of intentionally wounded trees are sought after by woodturners.
